results.title: Black berries
results.creator_credit: Ema Mulholland, Rosie Travers and AFTRS
results.brief_description:
Black Berries is a story about Candy and Lao, two 12 year old best friends. One fateful day while walking home, the girls come to a laneway - the short cut. Lao begins to walk down it but, in a moment of loyalty, Candy keeps a promise she made to her mother and chooses the long way home.
Cast includes Anne Louise Lambert.

results.title: Black belt Jones
results.creator_credit: Warner Bros Pictures, Fred Weintraub, Paul Heller and Robert Clouse
results.brief_description: Pop Boyd (Scatman Crothers) owns a thriving karate school near downtown Los Angeles. Unfortunately it sits on a piece of land upon which the local mob wants to build its own ‘civic centre’. When the gangsters’ muscling of Pop leads to tragedy, Black Belt Jones (Jim Kelly) steps forward to exact his own brand of lightning-charged revenge. Filmmaker Robert Crouse, who showcased Bruce Lee in ‘Enter the dragon’ and Jackie Chan in ‘The big brawl’, serves up masterful action sequences in which every move is choreographed like a ballet. Cast also includes Gloria Hendry, Eric Laneuville, Alan Weeks, Andre Philippe and Vincent Barbi. See also ‘Game of death’ (1978), ‘Enter the dragon’ (1973), ‘The big brawl’ (1980).

results.title: Black Beauty
results.creator_credit: Tigon Pictures, Chilton Film Productions, Tony Tenser and James Hill
results.brief_description: Adapted by Wolf Mankowitz from the classic children’s book by Anna Sewell, Black Beauty tells the story of a luckless horse who is passed from hand to hand but is finally restored to its original young master and has a happy retirement. Stars Mark Lester, Walter Slezak and Patrick Mower.

results.title: Black Beauty
results.brief_description: Animated version of the classic novel by Anna Sewell. Black Beauty has a good start in life. He is raised in the scenic English countryside, is taught by his mother to be a friend to man, and has a good master, Squire Gordon, and stableman, John Manley. Beauty’s view of the world is tarnished by Ginger, the mare who shares the stable, who is bitter and disappointed with mankind and urges Beauty to believe her sentiments. When Beauty is sold it appears that Ginger was right, as his new owners treat him as a job horse. It is only through Black Beauty’s courage and faith, instilled in him through his upbringing that Beauty learns to appreciate mankind again. Features the voices of David Gregory, Laurie Mann, Mike Evans and Barbara Stevens.

results.title: Black Australia (A)
results.creator_credit: Darrell Sibosado, Michael Brogan and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode number 13 of Series “Film Australia’s Australia”.
Film and video segments relevant to this topic have been selected with original footage accompanied by original soundtracks. This program represents aspects of Aboriginal culture in Australia, and focuses on Aboriginal identity. The program uses the unifying symbols found in what is now known as the Aboriginal flag. The three colours in the flag symbolise the Aboriginal way of perceiving: red (land and politics), black (identity and self determination), and yellow (art and spirituality). These three interlinked themes are explored in the film with a focus on stimulating deeper understanding by white Australia on Aboriginality, the attitudes of white Australians towards Aboriginal people, racism in Australia, both individual and institutional and the changes needed in attitude and action to achieve justice. Teacher’s Guide included. Presented by Annette Shun Wah. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: Black ash
results.brief_description: An account of a typical ‘lazy day’ by the river in Warburton which suddenly turns nasty when Bonnie and her friends realise the gravity of the fire. She recounts her anxiety and wanting to leave Warburton and her frustration at her family’s indecisions. She is stuck in Lysterfield after they evacuate with 17 people.

results.title: Black and white: uptight
results.brief_description: The myths that perpetuate prejudice against black people in society and the subtle ways that hate is learned are explored in this film. The social and economical differences that do exist between blacks and whites are caused by historical identities in education and economic opportunity - and are in some cases even perpetuated by laws. The riots that erupted in the cities throughout the United States forced basic issues of injustice to the surface for all Americans to face. There are no easy ways to solve the problems caused by prejudice, but examples are given of areas in which government, business, and black and white people are working together to wipe out the hatred and misunderstanding between the races. This film acquaints the viewer with the subtle and sometimes unconscious manifestation of prejudice as well as the more obvious. It will also encourage the viewer to look more closely at their own attitudes. Suitable for secondary years 7-12.

results.title: Black and white: a creative leisure film
results.brief_description: Children’s drawings in black and white. Finger and brush painting using poster colours and crayons. Shows the technique of applying paint with rollers over paper having a crayon drawing which remains distinct so as to obtain a reverse copy on dampened paper which looks like a negative print.

results.title: Black and white in South Africa
results.creator_credit: Ronald Dick, Nicholas Balla and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “The Commonwealth of Nations”.
South Africa, one of the largest members of the Commonwealth, a country with full self-government, has an acute race problem that causes dissension not only within its borders but within the Commonwealth and beyond. We see a country of fourteen million people where only one out of five is white. Edgar McInnis gives a dispassionate appraisal of the motivations behind the policy of apartheid and of whether the practice of segregation provides a satisfactory solution. This documentary provides a comprehensive overview of the history of South African colonisation, the apartheid system and the country’s political developments using re-enactments, drawings, interviews and historic footage. Narrated by Edgar McInnis.
